awd_titl_txt: Effects of Culture on the Association of Neuroticism with Adverse Outcomes
awd_abstract_narration:
Personality traits shape who we are - chatty or shy, conscientious or a little careless, calm and steady or prone to negative feelings. Traits also shape how people respond to us. One trait that is important for the quality of our relationships and well-being is neuroticism, the opposite of which is emotional stability. Neuroticism is defined as the tendency to react with strong and intense negative emotion to everyday experiences of threat, loss, and frustration. This trait has been linked to poor relationships and well-being. This project tests novel hypotheses about the role of culture in reducing vulnerability to negative relationship and well-being outcomes for those higher in neuroticism. The hypotheses are tested using various methods including daily experience, behavioral observation, and physiological stress reactivity within experimental and longitudinal research designs. The results of this project will innovatively inform how culture and processes linked to culture (such as social support) can enhance relationship quality and well-being.

The responses of others play an important role in the association of neuroticism with poor relationship quality and well-being. Recent studies by the researcher, Belinda Campos of the University of California Irvine, indicate that the poor outcomes typically associated with neuroticism are reduced in Latinas, a group whose culture distinctively emphasizes four characteristics in relationships: interdependence, physical proximity, social support, and positive emotion. This project examines the influence of culture on the association of neuroticism with adverse outcomes. The proposed research tests the novel hypothesis that distinctive features of Latino culture shape social responses, including acceptance and support, that are protective for those who have high levels of neuroticism. Hypotheses will be tested by examining everyday experience and social behavior in three cultures (Latino, Asian, European) in a longitudinal  study of same-culture, same-sex dyads. The influence of culture on relationship quality, well-being and physiological responses will be examined. This work innovatively investigates the complex interplay of personality, culture, and social processes. It will lead to discoveries of social processes that are protective for some people from interdependent cultures. These social and behavioral processes may be leveraged to enhance the well-being of all.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The Regents of the University of California

por.por_cntn:
Personality traits shape who we are - chatty or shy, conscientious or a little careless, calm and steady or prone to negative feelings. Personality traits also shape how people respond to us. One trait that is important for the quality of our relationships and well-being is neuroticism. Neuroticism is defined as the tendency to react with strong and intense negative emotion to everyday experiences of threat, loss, and frustration. This trait has been linked to poor relationships and well-being. This project sought to examine a set of novel hypotheses about the role of culture in reducing vulnerability to adverse relationships and well-being for those higher in neuroticism. The results of this work are starting to inform a better understanding of how culture, and processes linked to culture (e.g., social support) can enhance relationship quality and well-being, including for people who are higher in neuroticism. This work and other studies by Belinda Campos of the University of California Irvine indicate that the poor outcomes typically associated with neuroticism are reduced in Latinas, a group whose culture distinctively emphasizes four characteristics in relationships: interdependence, physical proximity, social support, and positive emotion. This work innovatively investigates the complex interplay of personality, culture, and social processes and the dataset that has been collected as part of this project will be generative for years to come. Over time, this work is expected to lead to discoveries and interventions that can be leveraged to be protective of the well-being of people of all backgrounds.

In addition to the scientific outcomes, this project has had two other important outcomes. First, it has provided training and professional development opportunities to graduate students and 90+ undergraduates who developed research skills and professional training that will benefit them in their future careers. Second, an online platform for distributing Spanish language versions of measures commonly used in psychological science has been developed so researchers can more readily include Spanish-speaking monolinguals in future studies.


Last Modified: 12/21/2023
Modified by: Belinda Campos
